releases.details: Released in a box set titled 'The E-Space Trilogy'
special_features: Commentary by Lalla Ward, John Leeson, Paul Joyce, script editor Christopher H. Bidmead, and Mat Irvine
The Dreaming - Cast and crew look back at the making of Warriors' Gate
The Boy with the Golden Star - Actor Matthew Waterhouse looks back on his time on Doctor Who
Lalla's Wardrobe - A fun trip through Romana's time on the show
Isolated Music Score by Peter Howell

notes: Final regular appearance of Lalla Ward as Romana and John Leeson as K9.
Graeme Harper made his directorial debut on the programme, though uncredited.
Director Paul Joyce was briefly fired during production but was rehired.
The production faced delays and issues including a strike by BBC carpenters.
The script has undergone significant rewrites largely influenced by its director and script editor.

in_universe_mythology: The Tharils are a race that can navigate timelines and have leonine features.
real_world_cultural_references: The story uses elements from Jean Cocteau's films and Australian Aboriginal Dreamtime mythology.
Characters are named after real-world figures such as Rorvik and Sagan.
items: The Gundan robots created by humans to fight the Tharils
Dwarf star alloy which is used to contain time-sensitives

continuity_notes: The story follows directly into 'The Keeper of Traken'.
Romana and K9's departure from the Doctor is addressed in later expanded universe materials.

plot.plot_summary: The crew of a spacecraft in a void attempt to escape using enslaved Tharils. The Fourth Doctor, Romana, and Adric end up in the same void where they meet the Tharil named Biroc. The enslaved Tharils are being exploited by a crew led by Captain Rorvik to navigate through this timeless void known as The Gateway. A series of timelines and philosophical implications about slavery and time travel unfold, leading to Romana deciding to remain and free the Tharils with Biroc, alongside K9 who stays due to his own unique condition.
